Symptoms:

On the Mac OS X Remote Desktop application, attempting to connect to the server results in a message stating "Connection refused".

Possible causes:

1. The most common cause (esp. for customers new to hosting) is a firewall or other network device blocking access to our hosting

servers. Usually, you'll want to ask them to get their IT involved. For reference, they need to allow the following port outbound for the IP

range listed below:

This issue must be fixed on the customer's end by their network administrator. Do not attempt to assist the customer with unblocking

our servers, apart from letting them know that they should not be blocking the above IP/port.

Please Note: This IP address is not used for allowing email servers to receive email communication from the hosting service.73

[VT_Error] Hosting Connection Drop-outs or Slowness

Symptoms:

On a regular basis, the screen turns black, the message "The connection has been lost" appears and/or the performance of the hosting

service is slower than expected.

Possible causes:

1. The hosting service is encountering difficulties.

(Unless multiple customers are encountering the same issue simultaneously, this is unlikely.)

ticket_content.ticket_title: Emails not working - sending from vettrak #67179
ticket_content.ticket_description: Emails not sending from vettrak. Saying Server Verification Fail.   How do we fix this?

response.answer:
Hi there,

Thank you for reaching out regarding the email sending issue in VETtrak. The "Server Verification Fail" error typically indicates a problem with the server certificate or SSL/TLS configuration [1].

Some potential causes and troubleshooting steps:

- The hostname entered in the 'Mail server address' field in VETtrak doesn't match the one on the certificate [1]
- The certificate has expired [1]
- The certificate is a self-signed certificate (VETtrak only accepts certificates signed by a trusted certificate authority) [1]

To troubleshoot, you can use the "Check TLS" service at https://www.checktls.com/TestReceiver to check the certificate being sent by the mail server. Enter the hostname as entered in the Email Preferences in VETtrak, and if using a different port from 587, also enter the port in the 'MX Port' field [1]. This will show the certificate given to VETtrak when connecting. If a verification error results, then VETtrak will not work either [1].

Additionally, you can try disabling TLS by setting the SSL/TLS option to 'None (no SSL)' and setting the port to 25 to use non-secure SMTP, although this is not recommended [1][2].

If the issue persists after trying these steps, please check the detailed error breakdown in the Email Wizard for more information [3]. Feel free to reach out with any additional details or questions.

Thank you,

Hi there,

Thank you for reaching out about the issue with emails not sending from VETtrak and showing the "Server Verification Fail" error.

The "276 Server certificate failed. Connection Aborted" error typically indicates that the certificate received from the mail server is not valid, which could be due to a few reasons:

1) The hostname entered in the 'Mail server address' field in VETtrak's Email Preferences doesn't match the one on the certificate [1]
2) The certificate has expired [1][2]
3) The certificate is a self-signed certificate, which VETtrak does not accept as it only allows certificates signed by a trusted certificate authority [1][2]

To troubleshoot this, you can use the "Check TLS" service at https://www.checktls.com/TestReceiver to verify the certificate being sent by your mail server. Enter the hostname as configured in VETtrak's Email Preferences, and if using a non-standard port, also enter that port number. This will show the certificate details VETtrak is receiving when connecting [1][2].

If a verification error occurs due to a self-signed certificate or other issue, VETtrak will not be able to send emails. You may need to update the hostname, renew the certificate, or obtain a trusted certificate signed by a certificate authority.

Additionally, please ensure the SSL/TLS Connection Method and Authentication Type settings in VETtrak's Email Preferences are correctly configured based on your mail server requirements [2].

Let me know if the issue persists after verifying the certificate and settings.

Hi there,

Thank you for reaching out regarding the email sending issue in VETtrak. The "Server Verification Fail" error typically indicates that the certificate received from the mail server is not valid. This can happen for a few reasons[1]:

- The hostname entered in the 'Mail server address' field in VETtrak doesn't match the one on the certificate
- The certificate has expired
- The certificate is a self-signed certificate (VETtrak only accepts certificates signed by a trusted certificate authority)

To troubleshoot this, you can use the "Check TLS" service at https://www.checktls.com/TestReceiver[2]. Enter the hostname as entered in the Email Preferences in VETtrak (if using a different port from 587, also click 'FULL version' and enter the port in the 'MX Port' field). This will show the certificate given to VETtrak when connecting. If a verification error results (e.g. due to a self-signed certificate), then VETtrak will not work either[1].

If the certificate checks out, the next step would be to review the error details provided in the Email Wizard[3]. Expand the details section to get a more detailed breakdown of the steps the mail server took when attempting to send the email. This information can help pinpoint where the process failed.

Please let me know if the issue persists after checking the certificate and reviewing the error details. I'd be happy to further assist in troubleshooting.

Kind Regards,

Email Issues and Troubleshooting

Types of Errors  There are two types of errors that you will see when attempting to send emails:   Dialog box

this takes the form of an error dialog that appears after a email has attempted to send. These indicate that the connection with the server was not successfully established. Status error - these show up against each email which could not be sent in the Email Wizard in the form of a red 'Status' indicator. Click the box to determine the error that occurred. If an email in the list appears with a green status indicator, this indicates the email was sent successfully, even if others in the list are marked red. The error code and message are produced by the mail server in this case. The message is provided by the email server and thus messages will vary depending on the SMTP server that is being connected to, even for the same error. When you encounter a Status Error, VETtrak does have the ability to display a more detailed breakdown of the steps your mailserver took when attempting to send the email. This is located in the bottom-right hand side of the wizard, and can be expanded like so:     These details should explain where the process failed, and if you need to send this information to VETtrak Support for troubleshooting you can press the Copy button and paste it into a VETtrak support email.

provide them with the IP address: 103.102.118.1. Note that email from VETtrak is relayed directly via their mail server by VETtrak - there is

no intermediary mail server involved (though some customers may assume there is).

Recently migrated customers

New customers who are using the hosting service, or have recently migrated to the hosting service may initially try to use details for their

local mail server. As out hosting servers are located on a different network to their mail server, this simply will not work. These can usually

be identified by the '11001: [11001] Host not found' error:

Alternatively, their mail server address may be accessible by the Internet but won't allow the user to "relay" email (i.e. deliver email to

a different email server other than itself). This will typically produce the '550 5.7.1: Unable to relay' error message (or similar) when sending

is attempted to any email address outside their own domain. In this case, it's usually possible to simply change the email preferences in

VETtrak to include authentication details for the email server, which will give the user permission to relay.

CODE MESSAGE EXPLANATION/RESOLUTION148

Troubleshooting errors

First steps

Prior to checking anything else, ensure that the following has been carried out:

1. Check 'File', 'Global preferences...', 'Email preferences' and ensure that settings are entered.

2. If the SSL setting is set to 'Automatic', try setting it to either 'None (no SSL)' or 'Explicit'. The automatic setting often chokes and it is

best to set the correct value manually. If you see errors regarding the 'STARTTLS' command - this is probably why.

Email error codes

Below is a list of email errors that can occur when attempting to send email in VETtrak. These take the form of a code and a message. For

server connection problems, you'll get a 5 digit code and a dialog box, for SMTP errors, you'll get a red 'Status' indicator and a 3 digit error

Hosted Customers  If you are hosted with VETtrak, please note that the firewall in our hosted environment only permits email to be sent out of standard SMTP ports (25, 465, and 587). If your mail server is on a non-standard port, please send an email to support@vettrak.io requesting that your mail server be unblocked, indicating the hostname and port number for your mail server. We will only accept unblock requests which specify the mail server hostname in the request. We will not unblock a port to allow connection to all mail servers, apart from the aforementioned standard SMTP ports. Troubleshooting Email Errors  Below is a list of email errors that can occur when attempting to send email in VETtrak. These take the form of a code and a message. For server connection problems, you'll get a 5 digit code and a dialog box, for SMTP errors, you'll get a red 'Status' indicator and a 3 digit error code (and possibly a sub-error code after this). The 'Message' column is an indication only and the actual error returned for a given code will depend on the SMTP server software in use. If your

error matches a code, even if the message is slightly different, it is most likely caused by the same issue as listed in the 'Explanation/resolution' column for that code. response.answer:
Hi *****,

Thank you for providing the details on the email sending issue you are experiencing in VETtrak after changing the password for the *************** account.

The error you are receiving "SMTP protocol error. 535 5.7.60 Authentication unsuccessful" indicates that VETtrak is unable to authenticate with the Office 365 SMTP server using the new password, even though the password has been updated in VETtrak's Email Preferences [1].

Microsoft has recently implemented more stringent security measures that require additional authentication beyond just a username and password when using Office 365 SMTP servers. This is likely the reason the new password is not being accepted [2].

To resolve this, you will need to set up an SMTP relay on your mail server as outlined in this Microsoft article: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/mail-flow-best-practices/how-to-set-up-a-multifunction-device-or-application-to-send-email-using-microsoft-365-or-office-365 [2]

Once the SMTP relay is configured by your IT team, you can update the VETtrak Email Preferences with the relay server details instead of the outlook.office365.com server. The Authentication Type will likely need to be set to "Not Required" as well [2].

Alternatively, if you have a small number of VETtrak users sending emails, you could set up individual application passwords in Office 365 for each user and configure VETtrak to use those credentials instead of the main email account password [4].

Please let me know if you need any other assistance in getting VETtrak email sending working again with your new Office 365 password.

Hi there,

Thank you for reaching out regarding the email sending issue in VETtrak. Based on the details provided, it seems that after changing the password for the email account used in VETtrak's Email Preferences, VETtrak is unable to authenticate with the mail server and send emails successfully [1].

A few things you can try to resolve this:

1. Double-check the email settings in VETtrak's Email Preferences to ensure the correct server address, port, SSL/TLS connection method, and authentication type are configured for your email service [1][6]. If using Office365 or Gmail, refer to our recommended settings in the Cloud Service Email Settings article [3].

2. If the settings appear correct, try sending a test email from within VETtrak again and review the log for any specific errors or information that could point to the issue [1][5]. Common errors like "Authentication unsuccessful" or "Unable to relay" often indicate incorrect authentication details or mail server permissions.

3. If you're using multi-factor authentication or an application-specific password for the email account, ensure the correct password is entered in VETtrak's Email Preferences [3].

4. Check if there are any firewall, antivirus, or security software rules that could be blocking VETtrak's connection to the mail server [1].

5. If you have VETtrak Security enabled and want each staff member to use their individual email account, ensure their email credentials are correctly configured in the Staff Manager [4].

If you continue to experience issues after trying these steps, please provide the specific error messages or log details, and I'll be happy to further investigate. Alternatively, you may need to reach out to your email service provider or IT team for assistance in configuring the correct settings for VETtrak.

Thank you,

Hi there,

Thank you for reaching out about the email sending issue in VETtrak after changing your email account password. The error message you provided ("535 5.7.14 Authentication unsuccessful") indicates that VETtrak is unable to authenticate with the email server using the new password [1].

To resolve this, please follow these steps:

1. Go to File > Global Preferences > Email Preferences in VETtrak.
2. Update the "Email login password" field with your new email account password.
3. If you are using Gmail, double check that the other settings match the recommended configuration in our guide [3].
4. Click "Send Test Email" to verify the new settings.

If you continue to receive a "276 Server certificate failed" error, this likely means the hostname entered in the "Mail server address" field does not match the server certificate, the certificate has expired, or it is a self-signed certificate (which VETtrak does not accept) [5].

For hosted VETtrak customers, if your mail server uses a non-standard SMTP port, please email support@vettrak.io with the hostname and port number so we can unblock the port in our firewall [7].

Let me know if the issue persists after trying these steps. I'd be happy to further investigate based on any additional error details you can provide.

Email Troubleshooting - Setting up an SMTP Relay

Microsoft and Google are deprecating basic SMTP authentication for Office365 and Gmail. VETtrak and all associated products currently only support SMTP (username and password) authentication so workarounds are needed in order to get past the requirement for Multi Factor Authentication. TABLE OF CONTENTS   Outlook/Office365  Gmail  OAuth 2.0      Outlook/Office365  If you use Office365 as well as the email function within the Trainer and Student Portal/VETenrol, an SMTP relay will need to be set up to get around the need for multi factor authentication. This will need to be configured by your IT team or Mail server admin using the steps in this Microsoft article. Within the article, Option 3 is the easiest to follow, depending on how the relay is set up the VETtrak email preferences can be filled out similarly to the below. SMTP Server: your mx endpoint  SSL/TLS: Automatic  Authentication Type: Not Required          Once this has been set up, you will also need to create a SPF Record, details of this are provided in the article here. Gmail  For Gmail/G Suite users, an application password can be configured within the privacy settings on the admin account, this will allow you to continue using SMTP without having to set up a relay. This is set up within the 2-Step verification options as detailed in this Google article.

Email Preferences  To configure VETtrak to send email via Gmail, go to File > Global preferences > Email preferences, and use the following settings:   Mail server address: smtp.gmail.com  Email port: 587  SL/TLS connection method: Explicit  Authentication type: User/Password  Email login username: Your full email address to your Google account  Email login password: Your password to your Google account  Default from address: The same as the Email login username      If you have VETtrak Security and want each VETtrak user to send email using their own Gmail account, you can instead tick Use individual staff member email logins and clear the Default from address:  Then go to the Staff Manager, find each staff member who logs into VETtrak, right-click the Personal node, select Edit staff member, and enter their email username and password on the third page of the Client Wizard:      NOTES:   When sending email, the From address of the email must match the Email Login Username, otherwise Gmail will discard the email as spam. If you are using Google or Microsoft's two-step verification feature (also known as "multi-factor authentication), you will need to generate an application-specific password for VETtrak. You would then use this password as the Email Login Password when setting up your email in VETtrak.

Email: Using Individual Staff Member Logins

If you have configured VETtrak to send emails via your mail server, you may wish to set up your VETtrak Users/Staff to send email via their own unique email address. These credentials are then managed within the Client Wizard where a person has been configured to be recognised as a Staff Member. Related: This option will only function if your VETtrak system has had it's email settings configured - for information on how to do this, please view the article listed below: Email Preferences When editing a Client that has been set up as a Staff Member, there is a unique section of the wizard dedicated to Staff Details:    Regarding Email settings for this Staff Member, there are two key areas on this screen:     Email Signature provides an area to prepare a signature to be attached to staff emails, with formatting options for text and images. The Email Username/Email Password fields allow you to enter the full credentials set up for this user via your mailserver information. The Send Test Email button will then provide the option to attempt to send a dummy email and ensure that the details are correct.

This often indicates one of the following:   The hostname that has been entered in the 'Mail server address' field in VETtrak doesn't match the one on the certificate  The certificate has expired  The certificate is a self-signed certificate - VETtrak only accepts certificates signed by a trusted certificate authority   To check the certificate being sent by the mail server, you can use the "Check TLS" service at https://www.checktls.com/TestReceiver - enter the hostname as entered in the Email Preferences in VETtrak (if you use a different port from 587, also click 'FULL version' and enter the port in the 'MX Port' field). This will show the certificate given to VETtrak when connecting. If a verification error results (e.g. due to a self-signed certificate), then VETtrak will not work either. Note that TLS can often be disabled by setting the SSL/TLS option to 'None (no SSL)' and setting the port to 25 to use non secure SMTP, however this is not recommended. 161: SMTP protocol error. 451 5.7.3   STARTTLS is required to send mail   This indicates that the SSL/TLS Connection Method and/or the Authentication Type are not configured correctly. These are configured within File -> Global Preferences -> Email Preferences. Refer to our Cloud Service Email Settings article and for further details on the recommended settings, and request your IT Team to provide any other details required to meet your organisation's needs.

provide them with the IP address: 103.102.118.1. Note that email from VETtrak is relayed directly via their mail server by VETtrak - there is

no intermediary mail server involved (though some customers may assume there is).

Recently migrated customers

New customers who are using the hosting service, or have recently migrated to the hosting service may initially try to use details for their

local mail server. As out hosting servers are located on a different network to their mail server, this simply will not work. These can usually

be identified by the '11001: [11001] Host not found' error:

Alternatively, their mail server address may be accessible by the Internet but won't allow the user to "relay" email (i.e. deliver email to

a different email server other than itself). This will typically produce the '550 5.7.1: Unable to relay' error message (or similar) when sending

is attempted to any email address outside their own domain. In this case, it's usually possible to simply change the email preferences in

VETtrak to include authentication details for the email server, which will give the user permission to relay.

CODE MESSAGE EXPLANATION/RESOLUTION148

Troubleshooting errors

First steps

Prior to checking anything else, ensure that the following has been carried out:

1. Check 'File', 'Global preferences...', 'Email preferences' and ensure that settings are entered.

2. If the SSL setting is set to 'Automatic', try setting it to either 'None (no SSL)' or 'Explicit'. The automatic setting often chokes and it is

best to set the correct value manually. If you see errors regarding the 'STARTTLS' command - this is probably why.

Email error codes

Below is a list of email errors that can occur when attempting to send email in VETtrak. These take the form of a code and a message. For

server connection problems, you'll get a 5 digit code and a dialog box, for SMTP errors, you'll get a red 'Status' indicator and a 3 digit error

Hosted Customers  If you are hosted with VETtrak, please note that the firewall in our hosted environment only permits email to be sent out of standard SMTP ports (25, 465, and 587). If your mail server is on a non-standard port, please send an email to support@vettrak.io requesting that your mail server be unblocked, indicating the hostname and port number for your mail server. We will only accept unblock requests which specify the mail server hostname in the request. We will not unblock a port to allow connection to all mail servers, apart from the aforementioned standard SMTP ports. Troubleshooting Email Errors  Below is a list of email errors that can occur when attempting to send email in VETtrak. These take the form of a code and a message. For server connection problems, you'll get a 5 digit code and a dialog box, for SMTP errors, you'll get a red 'Status' indicator and a 3 digit error code (and possibly a sub-error code after this). The 'Message' column is an indication only and the actual error returned for a given code will depend on the SMTP server software in use. If your

error matches a code, even if the message is slightly different, it is most likely caused by the same issue as listed in the 'Explanation/resolution' column for that code. Serve     10013  Access denied  VETtrak has been blocked from opening the connection to the mail server. Try disabling any firewall/anti-virus software as this commonly blocks SMTP to prevent viruses mass emailing. If emailing works after having disabled security software, you will likely need to

[VT_Error] Portal Error and Troubleshooting

54

[VT_Error] Trainer Portal Email Troubleshooting

Trainer Portal email errors typically do not give any information as to what causes them, there are a few things that can be checked in order

to get to the bottom of the issue quickly.

First, the email preferences will need to be checked within VETtrak, within there you’ll be able to check whether the SMTP server details are

misconfigured. If the customer is using Office365 or Gmail, you can compare the details they’ve got configured with the examples in the

Cloud Service Email Settings article to see whether anything is off. In the majority of cases you would expect that either an Office365 or

Gmail server setup would adhere to the details listed in that article as they are standardised.

In cases where a customer is using an SMTP Relay or a mail service other than Gmail or Office365, it is hard to tell whether the details they

have configured are correct. This usually calls for getting their IT team or Mail server admin involved but there are a few things you can in

order to troubleshoot this.

The example below shows an SMTP relay set up for Office365, typically a set up like this would be sending from port 25, port 587 usually

requires the SSL/TLS connection method to be set to explicit and also requires the mail to be authenticated.

55

In essence, even without standardised details it is worth keeping an eye out for anything that may be off within an SMTP configuration as a

first point of call.

If everything seems to be in order with their SMTP details, the next step is to send a test email from within VETtrak - this will bring up an

Portal SMTP override options

Must be running VETtrak version 18.3.0.x (or higher)  and Trainer Portal v18.3.0.2 (or higher)  or Student Portal v18.3.0.2 (or higher)  It is important that an experienced IT resource is available to manage this process. Version 19.2 (or higher) of the portals and onwards will not need this over-ride, unless using NTLM email. Feature summary  As from version 18.3.0.2 there is an option to override the VETtrak configured SMTP provider. The override allows configuration to be sourced from the Web.config file, instead of the settings stored in VETtrak. Note: The default configuration set up in VETtrak is generally sufficient for most customer's email needs, and this override option covers some edge cases for where the VETtrak configuration works for VETtrak desktop software but does not work with the Trainer Portal such as NTLM with individual account authorisation. Web Config options explained. OverrideSmtpSettings  Enables or disables mail server settings configured in this file. The SMTP Settings:   SmtpServerHostname,  SmtpServerPort,  SmtpServerSslMode,  SmtpServerAuthType, SmtpServerUsername and SmtpServerPassword   must be provided if this option is set to "true". true: The SMTP server settings in the web.config file will be used for sending email false: The SMTP server settings configured in VETtrak will be used for sending email  <add key="UseLegacySmtpClient" value="false" /   SmtpServerHostname  The hostname of the SMTP server for sending email.

If VETtrak is using email addresses for usernames, ValidateUser and ValidateClient will check your specified username against the clients' email addresses if no client with that username was found, and will allow login with that email address if only one client has that email address. Password policy settings. VETtrak can now be configured with password policy settings such as minimum password length and the categories of characters required. UpdateClientUsernamePassword will validate the new password against this policy. The new GetPasswordPolicy function returns the current password policy settings that you can use to validate new passwords. To avoid additional breaking changes, the API does not enforce the new "Force password change on next login if current password doesn't comply with policy", "Require passwords to be changed every X days", or "User must change password at next login" settings in VETtrak. You can continue to log into the API with a username/password for a client to whom any of these conditions apply without being forced to change the password. However, if the default vettrak/trakker credentials are being used for the API, and a user logs into VETtrak with those default credentials, VETtrak will force the user to change the password, which may then require your configured password to log into the API be changed.

ticket_content.ticket_title: *********** Authentication unsuccessful, the request did not meet the criteria to be authenticated successfully. Contact your administrator. #68662
ticket_content.ticket_description: Hi Team,      User with MFA is having issues sending emails out from Vettrack using their individual login. They are receiving: *** *.*.*** Authentication unsuccessful, the request did not meet the criteria to be authenticated successfully. Contact your administrator.   Vettrack is setup using ****************** *** and unsure if this needs to be changed, can you confirm?   I ve followed the guides below and I can see I already have a connector but it has IP s included. Would I need to make a new one and use either address below?  smtp.picac.vic.edu.au  picac edu ******************************  picac emailsecurity.in.tmes ******************  ********************************************************************how to set up a multifunction device or application to send email using microsoft *** or office ***  ************************************************************************ creating a spf record to avoid mail being classified as spam     If you could please confirm any required changes I need to make on Vettrack side and if you are able to assist with the questions above. Thank you.

response.answer:
Hi there,

Thank you for reaching out regarding the email sending issue with individual staff logins and multi-factor authentication (MFA) enabled in VETtrak.

The error "Authentication unsuccessful, the request did not meet the criteria to be authenticated successfully. Contact your administrator" typically indicates that an application-specific password is required when using MFA with VETtrak [1]. To resolve this, you will need to generate an application-specific password for VETtrak within your Microsoft 365 account. Once generated, you can enter this password in the 'Email password' field for the affected staff member in the Client Wizard [3].

Regarding the email server settings, if you are using Office 365 (Microsoft 365) for your email, the default VETtrak email preferences should work without needing to change the SMTP server address. However, if you are still experiencing issues after setting up the application-specific password, you may need to adjust the settings based on your specific email configuration.

For the connector setup, if you have already configured a connector with IP addresses included, you should not need to create a new one. The provided SMTP server addresses (smtp.picac.vic.edu.au and picac.emailsecurity.in.tmes.com) are likely for a different email service provider, and may not be relevant for your Office 365 setup.

As for setting up an SPF record to avoid mail being classified as spam, you can refer to our guide on creating an SPF record [4]. This guide provides a suggested SPF record format that includes our VETtrak mail servers, which you can add to your existing SPF record or create a new one if you don't have one set up already.

Please let me know if you have any further questions or if you need additional assistance with configuring VETtrak to work with your Office 365 email and MFA setup.

Thank you,

Hi there,

The error "Authentication unsuccessful, the request did not meet the criteria to be authenticated successfully. Contact your administrator" typically indicates that two-factor authentication (2FA) or multi-factor authentication (MFA) has been enabled on the Gmail account you are trying to send emails from [2]. 

To resolve this issue, you will need to set up an application-specific password for VETtrak within your Google account. This application-specific password can then be entered in the 'Email password' field for the affected staff member in the VETtrak Client Wizard [2][5].

Here are the steps to create an application-specific password:

1. Sign in to your Google Account and go to the "Security" section under "Sign-in & security".
2. Under "Signing in to Google", click on "App Passwords".
3. Follow the prompts to generate a new app password for VETtrak.
4. In VETtrak, go to the Client Wizard for the affected staff member and enter their email address in the "Email username" field and the app password in the "Email password" field.

This should resolve the authentication issue and allow the staff member to send emails from VETtrak using their individual login with MFA enabled [1].

Regarding the SMTP server address and connector settings, the current configuration using *********** *** should work as long as the individual staff member credentials are set up correctly. You should not need to create a new connector or change the SMTP server address unless advised by your IT team.

Please let me know if the issue persists after setting up the app password or if you have any other questions.

Hi,

Thank you for reaching out regarding the issue with sending emails from VETtrak using individual staff member logins when Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) is enabled.

The error message "Authentication unsuccessful, the request did not meet the criteria to be authenticated successfully. Contact your administrator" indicates that the authentication process is failing due to MFA being enabled on the email account [1].

To resolve this issue, you will need to generate an application-specific password for VETtrak within your Google/G Suite account [2]. This application-specific password should then be used as the "Email Login Password" when setting up the individual staff member's email credentials in the Client Wizard [3].

Please follow these steps:

1. Go to your Google/G Suite account settings and enable "App Passwords" or "Application-specific passwords" under the "Security" section.
2. Generate a new app password specifically for VETtrak.
3. In VETtrak, go to the Client Wizard for the affected staff member and enter their email address in the "Email Username" field.
4. In the "Email Password" field, enter the application-specific password you generated in step 2.
5. Click "Send Test Email" to verify the settings are working correctly.

Regarding the SMTP server settings, the details you have provided (*****************) should work as long as they are configured correctly in VETtrak's Email Preferences. However, if you continue to face issues, you may need to update the SMTP server hostname and port based on the information provided by your email administrator.

For setting up the SPF record, the guide you referred to should provide the necessary steps. If you need further assistance, please let me know.

Please let me know if the issue persists after following these steps or if you have any other questions.

Thank you,

161: SMTP protocol error. 554 5.2.0

'Submission.Exception:SendAsDenied'   This indicates that someone has attempted to reference an email address that is different to the configured 'Send As' email account in the preferences. Essentially unless the mail server has been configured in a specific way, you can't Send as one user, and then try and specify a Reply Address as someone else. Commonly this is fixed by using Individual Staff Member Log Ins or making sure the Reply To address is the same as the Sender email address. 161: SMTP protocol error  Service unavailable, Client host [103.102.118.1] blocked using Spamhaus. This indicates the authentication settings may be missing within VETtrak. Check the settings entered in 'File', 'Global preferences', 'Email preferences'. You will need to ensure the SSL/TLS connection method is 'Explicit', and change the Auth type to username/password and enter a valid email address and password that is accepted by your email server. 161: SMTP protocol error. 534 5.7.14  Username and Password not accepted  This usually indicates that you may be unable to email through Gmail. If comfortable, test enabling “Access for less secure apps” (which just means the client/app doesn’t use OAuth 2.0 - https://oauth.net/2/) for the account you are trying to access.

It's found in the account settings on the Security tab -> Account permissions. https://support.google.com/accounts/answer/6010255  535-5.7.14  Follow on Error   This is usually a follow on from the above error ^  Go to

https://accounts.google.com/DisplayUnlockCaptcha

and click Continue. Then you can authenticate your Additional Email Address from your Gmail Account. 552 5.2.3

Guidelines. y3-20020a17090a134300b0022bb9f05753sm6843806pjf.48 - gsmtp. This indicates the file being sent exceeds a file size limit of 25MB while using Google as an SMTP provider. The file will need to be reduced in size, or in the case of a report, reduced volume of Data Entry to resolve the issue. See Gmail SMTP errors and codes for more information. 535 5.7.8  Bad Credentials   This indicates that two factor authentication has been enabled on your gmail account and as such, an application specific password will need to be set up in order for emailing to work through VETtrak. The following article steps you through the process of creating this within your google/G suite account. Those details can then be entered within your email preferences in the password field. Sign in with app passwords - Google Account Help   535 5.7.139   Authentication unsuccessful, the request did not meet the criteria to be authenticated successfully. Contact your administrator.

Email Preferences  To configure VETtrak to send email via Gmail, go to File > Global preferences > Email preferences, and use the following settings:   Mail server address: smtp.gmail.com  Email port: 587  SL/TLS connection method: Explicit  Authentication type: User/Password  Email login username: Your full email address to your Google account  Email login password: Your password to your Google account  Default from address: The same as the Email login username      If you have VETtrak Security and want each VETtrak user to send email using their own Gmail account, you can instead tick Use individual staff member email logins and clear the Default from address:  Then go to the Staff Manager, find each staff member who logs into VETtrak, right-click the Personal node, select Edit staff member, and enter their email username and password on the third page of the Client Wizard:      NOTES:   When sending email, the From address of the email must match the Email Login Username, otherwise Gmail will discard the email as spam. If you are using Google or Microsoft's two-step verification feature (also known as "multi-factor authentication), you will need to generate an application-specific password for VETtrak. You would then use this password as the Email Login Password when setting up your email in VETtrak.

If you don’t have any kind of SPF record for your domain, here is a suggested version for allowing mail from VETtrak mail servers:  v=spf1 include:spf.hbtoutbound.vettrak.com.au ?all  If you already have an SPF record please ensure that the VETtrak IPs 103.102.118.1 and 103.102.118.9 are added, or include our SPF record spf.hbtoutbound.vettrak.com.au   While we do not anticipate any change to the outgoing IP address of our network in Hobart due to us owning the IP range, including our SPF record has the benefit of not requiring any change on your end if a network change does occur. The method for updating these DNS entries will vary depending on your provider.

This often indicates one of the following:   The hostname that has been entered in the 'Mail server address' field in VETtrak doesn't match the one on the certificate  The certificate has expired  The certificate is a self-signed certificate - VETtrak only accepts certificates signed by a trusted certificate authority   To check the certificate being sent by the mail server, you can use the "Check TLS" service at https://www.checktls.com/TestReceiver - enter the hostname as entered in the Email Preferences in VETtrak (if you use a different port from 587, also click 'FULL version' and enter the port in the 'MX Port' field). This will show the certificate given to VETtrak when connecting. If a verification error results (e.g. due to a self-signed certificate), then VETtrak will not work either. Note that TLS can often be disabled by setting the SSL/TLS option to 'None (no SSL)' and setting the port to 25 to use non secure SMTP, however this is not recommended. 161: SMTP protocol error. 451 5.7.3   STARTTLS is required to send mail   This indicates that the SSL/TLS Connection Method and/or the Authentication Type are not configured correctly. These are configured within File -> Global Preferences -> Email Preferences. Portal SMTP override options

Must be running VETtrak version 18.3.0.x (or higher)  and Trainer Portal v18.3.0.2 (or higher)  or Student Portal v18.3.0.2 (or higher)  It is important that an experienced IT resource is available to manage this process. Version 19.2 (or higher) of the portals and onwards will not need this over-ride, unless using NTLM email. Feature summary  As from version 18.3.0.2 there is an option to override the VETtrak configured SMTP provider. The override allows configuration to be sourced from the Web.config file, instead of the settings stored in VETtrak. Note: The default configuration set up in VETtrak is generally sufficient for most customer's email needs, and this override option covers some edge cases for where the VETtrak configuration works for VETtrak desktop software but does not work with the Trainer Portal such as NTLM with individual account authorisation. Web Config options explained. OverrideSmtpSettings  Enables or disables mail server settings configured in this file. The SMTP Settings:   SmtpServerHostname,  SmtpServerPort,  SmtpServerSslMode,  SmtpServerAuthType, SmtpServerUsername and SmtpServerPassword   must be provided if this option is set to "true". true: The SMTP server settings in the web.config file will be used for sending email false: The SMTP server settings configured in VETtrak will be used for sending email  <add key="UseLegacySmtpClient" value="false" /   SmtpServerHostname  The hostname of the SMTP server for sending email.

If you are certain the details are correct, they may need to enable less secure apps in their Gmail settings. See Cloud Service Email Settings for more information about configuring VETtrak for Gmail. 535 5.7.3  Authentication unsuccessful  This indicates the authentication settings are not correct. Check the settings entered in 'File', 'Global preferences', 'Email preferences'. If 'Use individual staff member email logins' is ticked, go into the Client Wizard for the affected staff member and ask them to verify the details listed against 'Email username' and 'Email password'. 550 5.7.1  Unable to relay  The user does not have permission to send emails to an external domain. This is usually caused by missing user credentials in 'File', 'Global preferences', 'Email preferences'. 276  Server certificate verification failed. Connection Aborted. This error indicates that the certificate received from the mail server isn't valid.

Email: Using Individual Staff Member Logins

If you have configured VETtrak to send emails via your mail server, you may wish to set up your VETtrak Users/Staff to send email via their own unique email address. These credentials are then managed within the Client Wizard where a person has been configured to be recognised as a Staff Member. Related: This option will only function if your VETtrak system has had it's email settings configured - for information on how to do this, please view the article listed below: Email Preferences When editing a Client that has been set up as a Staff Member, there is a unique section of the wizard dedicated to Staff Details:    Regarding Email settings for this Staff Member, there are two key areas on this screen:     Email Signature provides an area to prepare a signature to be attached to staff emails, with formatting options for text and images. The Email Username/Email Password fields allow you to enter the full credentials set up for this user via your mailserver information. The Send Test Email button will then provide the option to attempt to send a dummy email and ensure that the details are correct.

SMTP Server

SMTP Server is a section of the Integration page in VETenrol Admin, which is available from the Configuration (). These settings are to connect to a SMTP mail server in order to send emails from VETenrol. Click the Mail tab on the Integration page to view them. There are two sections:   SMTP Server — Connection details and credentials for the server. Mail Settings — Shows the from address that will be used for emails sent by the specified server. SMTP Server  Completing these details will enable VETenrol to send all automated notifications via the specified mail server instead of using the VETtrak company mail server (not the details entered in the email preferences of the VETtrak software). Your VETtrak mail server settings may assist with completing the settings for VETenrol. Enter the Server address. For example: smtp.yourcompany.com.au  Enter the Username to access the server. Specify the Port the server uses for sending mail. Tick Use SSL/TLS secure connection, if applicable. Click the Save button for the page to commit the change. Important If your mail server uses a port that is NOT the default 25 or 587, please let us know so we can unblock that port on our firewall. Once the details are saved, a button will appear in the bottom corner of the section. Click the Set Password button. This will open a pop up. Enter your Password. Click the Set Password button. Once the password has been set, the section will include an additional button in the bottom corner.

Ticket Subject: Disability Services Australia - Email relay

Hi, I believe that you ve been speaking with my colleague **** regarding an issue that we re having with sending emails using the VETtrack application. We have recently enabled Multi Factor Authentication using Okta and so direct SMTP login to the Office *** mail servers is no longer possible and the previously suggested fix of using application passwords will not work because we are not using the Azure MFA system. My understanding of VETtrack is that it is hosted on your servers that users here remote desktop in to, is this correct? If this is the case then I can only see four solutions:   *. An SMTP relay solution is provided within VETtrack s systems   *. Outlook is installed on the hosted RDP servers so that this email client is used to authenticate and relay the emails   *. DSA set up an SMTP relay server of our own. Note that this will only work if the RDP servers  public IP remains the same to allow firewall rules   *. VETtrack is installed directly on DSA PCs for anyone needing to use it. Option two  Outlook  seems to be the fastest and easiest solution, I do not have a lot of experience with VETtrak s back end so I m not sure how viable option four is. I would prefer the two SMTP relay server options to be last resorts as it would not allow the emails being sent to be saved and tracked using the Office *** servers. If you have any other alternatives or experience with clients using Office *** with non Azure MFA I ll be happy to work with you on it.

response.answer:
Hi [Name],

Thank you for reaching out regarding the "Failed to send one or more VETEnrol email notifications" error. This error typically occurs when there is an issue with the SMTP server settings configured in the VETEnrol Admin portal [2][3]. 

To resolve this, I would suggest following these steps:

1. Log into the VETEnrol Admin portal and navigate to the Configuration > Integrations > Mail tab [1].
2. Review the SMTP Server and Mail Settings details to ensure they are correct for your email server [1].
3. If using Office 365 or Gmail, compare the details to the examples in our Cloud Service Email Settings guide [4].
4. For other email services, you may need to consult your IT team or mail server admin to verify the correct settings [5].
5. Once the settings are updated, click "Save" and then use the "Test SMTP Settings" button to confirm the test email is received [1].

If the test email is successful, the issue should be resolved going forward. However, if you continue receiving this error, please let me know and I can further investigate.

To check how many registrations were affected, you can view the Reports > Mail Summary in the VETEnrol Admin [6]. This will show any failed email notifications during the specified date range.

Please let me know if you have any other questions or concerns!

Kind Regards,
[Your name]

Hi *****,

Thank you for reaching out regarding the "Failed to send one or more VETEnrol email notifications" error. This error typically occurs when there is an issue with the SMTP server settings configured in VETenrol, preventing it from sending out automated email notifications successfully [2].

To resolve this, I would suggest following these steps:

1. Log in to the VETenrol Admin portal and navigate to the Configuration > Integrations page [1].
2. Under the SMTP Server section, verify that the server address, username, port number, and SSL/TLS setting are correct for your email server [1].
3. If any details are incorrect, update them and click "Save". Then click "Set Password" to enter the correct password for the SMTP server [1].
4. After saving the changes, click the "Test SMTP Settings" button to send a test email. If the test is successful, the issue should be resolved [1].

If the test email fails or you continue to receive the error, there may be an issue with your email server or firewall settings. In that case, you may need to consult with your IT team or email service provider for further assistance.

Regarding the number of affected registrations, you can check the Mail Summary Report under the Reports menu in the VETenrol Admin portal. This report should provide details on the specific registrations where email notifications failed to send [2].

Please let me know if you have any other questions or need further assistance in resolving this issue [3].

Kind Regards,

Hi *****,

Thank you for reaching out regarding the failed VETenrol email notifications. This error typically occurs when there is an issue with the SMTP server settings configured in VETenrol [2]. Here are a few steps you can take to resolve this:

1. Check the SMTP Server settings in VETenrol Admin under Configuration > Integrations > Mail tab [1]. Ensure the server address, username, port, and SSL/TLS setting are correct for your email server. You can refer to your VETtrak email server settings as a guide.

2. Test the SMTP settings by clicking the "Test SMTP Settings" button [1]. If the test email is not received, there is likely an issue with the credentials or settings.

3. Check if your email server has any restrictions or firewall rules that may be blocking emails from the VETenrol server [7]. You may need to whitelist the VETenrol server IP or create an SPF record.

4. Review the Email Alerts settings in VETenrol Admin under Configuration > VETenrol Admin Preferences [8]. Ensure the email addresses listed are current and correct.

5. Check the Mail Summary report in VETenrol Admin under Reports to see which specific registrations were affected by the failed notifications [2][3].

Once you have updated the SMTP settings, the notifications should start sending successfully again. Let me know if you continue to experience issues after trying these steps [1].

Thank you,

These settings are to connect to a SMTP mail server in order to send emails from VETenrol. Click the Mail tab on the Integration page to view them. There are two sections:   SMTP Server — Connection details and credentials for the server. Mail Settings — Shows the from address that will be used for emails sent by the specified server. Automated email notifications for new VETenrol registrations are not being received

If you are not receiving alerts for new registrations:   Check the email alerts setting is enabled in your VETenrol Admin. Check the email address specified for alerts is still current. Check your junk/spam and clutter folders in your mail client. Try sending a test email using the Test SMTP Settings button from the Mail tab of the Integrations page, available from the Configuration page. If you do not receive the test email, there may be an issue with the credentials entered for your SMTP server.

VETenrol session time

out

When a participant attempting to enrol receives this error, the most common causes are explained within the error text provided. These are:   The registration page was left unattended for a period of time. The length of time is generous, for example a user could leave it to make a coffee without concern, however if it is left overnight, there will likely be an error if they try to continue with it in the morning. The participant is trying to return to their registration, or to VETenrol in general, using a favourited/bookmarked link. Essentially the same as the above, since once a user visits VETenrol with a valid link the URL is replaced with the session link. If the user saves that link with the intention of returning later they're essentially leaving it "unattended" and the session will expire. The VETtrak API timeout period has been exceeded. VETenrol authenticates with the API in order to communicate with VETtrak through-out the session. Successful authentication issues a token to VETenrol which is like a free pass to keep using the API, but there is an expiry and access attempts after that will result in an error. For security, a participant generally must complete their registration in the one sitting and in a timely manner unless they make use of the Save for Later feature. They must use a valid link to reach VETenrol, such as from your website or their Save For Later email, and not a link saved from a previous visit or found in their browser history.

Stripe Dashboard->Developers to see this info.

Payment Gateway surcharges and additional fees

There are no additional fees or surcharges, regardless of the payment method used by registrants. Payment Providers (i.e Stripe) may take

a cut of the charge, however we don’t take any part of that. Unless the customer is on Enterprise+, it is a flat $4 per registration.

[VT_Informational] VETenrol SMTP FAQ

Where to access SMTP Settings

For when it comes to emailing out of VETenrol, there is a separate area for managing SMTP settings from what is used in VETtrak, which

will need to be filled in if you would like to send emails out of VETenrol.

Depending on the version of VETenrol you are using, the ways to get there will vary, however both versions we support will be listed below

to cover all bases;

1. New Client Admin VETenrol;

Once signed into the Client Admin Portal for VETenrol, click on the Configuration Cog wheel in the top-right corner

Select the Integration Panel

Under SMTP Server, enter the same details as featured in VETtrak, ensuring 'Use SSL/TLS secure connection?' is also ticked to

indicate the SSL/TLS Method is Explicit

Click Save

Click Test SMTP Settings to confirm whether the test email goes through.

2. Old Client Admin VETenrol;

Along the top row, click Settings -> General Settings

224

Scroll down to the SMTP Settings panel, enter the same details as featured in VETtrak, ensuring 'Use SSL/TLS secure

connection?' is also ticked to indicate the SSL/TLS Method is Explicit.

Click Save

Click Test SMTP Settings to confirm whether the test email goes through.

SMTP Server Set up with Office 365

You will need to use authentication (tick secure checkbox, use port 587) and also provide the username/password of a licensed Office 365

user - it is also possible to set up an email address for this purpose.

The following support article from Microsoft, may assist:

VETtrak Desktop

[VT_Error] Trainer Portal Email Troubleshooting

Trainer Portal email errors typically do not give any information as to what causes them, there are a few things that can be checked in order

to get to the bottom of the issue quickly.

First, the email preferences will need to be checked within VETtrak, within there you’ll be able to check whether the SMTP server details are

misconfigured. If the customer is using Office365 or Gmail, you can compare the details they’ve got configured with the examples in the

Cloud Service Email Settings article to see whether anything is off. In the majority of cases you would expect that either an Office365 or

Gmail server setup would adhere to the details listed in that article as they are standardised.

In cases where a customer is using an SMTP Relay or a mail service other than Gmail or Office365, it is hard to tell whether the details they

have configured are correct. This usually calls for getting their IT team or Mail server admin involved but there are a few things you can in

order to troubleshoot this.

The example below shows an SMTP relay set up for Office365, typically a set up like this would be sending from port 25, port 587 usually

requires the SSL/TLS connection method to be set to explicit and also requires the mail to be authenticated.

55

In essence, even without standardised details it is worth keeping an eye out for anything that may be off within an SMTP configuration as a

first point of call.

If everything seems to be in order with their SMTP details, the next step is to send a test email from within VETtrak - this will bring up an

DELTA Registration System where the RTO has been given access.

[VT_Error] MSSQL VETtrak Autonumbers Jumping By 1000

At times, a VETtrak SQL customer may suddenly find one of their autonumbers jumping up by a factor of 1000, for example:

Client 1: VETtrak Code allocated upon creation = 0001

This is an explanation I sent to a customer:

This issue is actually caused by something within MicroSoft SQL Server that is considered a 'feature' (according to Microsoft).

I am no MSSQL expert, but the details provided to me by technicians with more thought on the matter clarify that the jump in the numbering

Creating a SPF record to avoid mail being classified as spam

Emails sent via VETenrol and VETsurvey originate from VETtrak servers. These servers are external to your organisation and this can cause some confusion, especially if you are trying to email someone else within your organisation. If you set up as the main email address in VETenrol or VETsurvey as say info@yourorganisation.com and you are trying to send an email to john@yourorganisation.com via VETenrol or VETsurvey, info@yourorganisation.com becomes the sending address. To your mail server it looks as though external parties are trying to send email to an internal addresses and to a mail server they look as though they are spam and subsequently these messages may either get blocked by your mail server or marked as spam. To avoid emails being trapped as spam in this situation adding an SPF record to your organisations DNS settings may be useful. An SPF record is a type of Domain Name Service (DNS) record that identifies which mail servers are permitted to send email on behalf of your domain. The purpose of an SPF record is to prevent spammers from sending messages with forged From addresses at your domain. Now its hard to give an exact rule for every organisation. Some may already have a SPF record that needs updating, others may not have one at all.

Email Alerts

Settings for Email Alerts are accessed from the Configuration () page in the VETenrol Admin, via the link under VETenrol Admin Preferences. These settings relate to automated email notifications for staff members regarding user activity. Features of the Email Alerts page:   Mail Server button — Navigate to the Integration page for SMTP Server details and mail settings. Save button — Click to commit changes made to the settings. The settings are divided into the following sections:   Registrations  Enquiries  Eligibilities   Each section has an option to enable email alerts for the activity type related to the section. When enabled, the email address where the alert should be sent must be entered. Multiple email addresses for the one type can be included by separating each address with a semi-colon. In the case of the Registrations section, there is also an option for Staff Member Alerts where an email will be sent to the staff member(s) assigned to the occurrence in VETtrak each time someone registers.

This email template can be used by the client manager, by right-clicking an occurrence enrolment and choosing Email client, or from the programme manager via the Enrolments branch of an occurrence (all enrolments, or individually by selecting a client after expanding Enrolments). User Experience  The student receiving and clicking on a data completion link will be presented with a page similar to the following:    The screenshot depicts our demo branding, but your organisation's branding will be applied. Related Topics  Data completions settings are configured in VETenrol Admin:   Client Data Completions to list details of newly completed collections. Data Completion Settings to control the steps in the collection process. Show study reason on confirm step option available from Registration Steps which can help facilitate data completions. Mail Templates for VETenrol.

Emergency contact email incorrectly limited to 20 characters. Parent workflow validation required the given name when the single name checkbox was enabled. Employers selected using autocomplete with & in their name would pass back into VETtrak with & (html equivalent of &)  Admin: Referral Source list for the Redirect feature listed inactive Referral Sources. VETenrol 23.4.0.2  Version released Dec 14th, 2023. Bug Fixes   Fixed case-sensitivity for the cache reset link. Fixed issue where a returning participant's postal details would be inserted as their residential address. Fixed issue when a direct occurrence link resulted in Employer auto-complete list being restricted to the list of registered employers set in VETenrol Admin.
